title: How to Bleed an Oil Furnace

steps.title: Turn the furnace off before starting any work on the fuel pump.
steps.content: Turn the furnace off before starting any work on the fuel pump . [1] X Research source Depending on your model, you may need to flip a switch near your furnace or turn it off at the breaker. You should also turn off the gas using the shut-off valve connected to the gas line.

steps.title: Locate the bleed screw on the fuel pump near where the fuel line comes in.
steps.content: Locate the bleed screw on the fuel pump near where the fuel line comes in. The screw is usually a small nipple-like screw. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Place a small bucket or pan under the bleed screw.
steps.content: Place a small bucket or pan under the bleed screw. The bucket will catch any fuel that sputters out as you bleed an oil furnace. If the screw is in an area that is impossible to put a bucket or small tray under, use a flexible tubing just big enough to fit over the bleed screw. Place the tube over the bleed screw and direct it to an area where you can fit the tray or bucket.

steps.title: Use a small crescent wrench or pliers to slightly loosen the bleed screw.
steps.content: Use a small crescent wrench or pliers to slightly loosen the bleed screw. Make sure the screw remains on the pump and is only a little loose, so it doesn’t fall completely off when you bleed the oil furnace. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Push the reset button on the furnace to turn it back on.
steps.content: Push the reset button on the furnace to turn it back on. As the furnace starts to suck fuel in, air and fuel will spit out of the bleed screw. [4] X Research source Keep your pliers or wrench on the screw ready to tighten it. This will also ensure the screw remains in place, if you did loosen it too much. If the furnace cycle ends before the air and fuel mixture stops sputtering, you’ll need to push the reset button again to continue the bleed process until the furnace pushes out all the air from the line. Some furnaces may have a lockout system that won’t allow you to reset more than one or two times. If this happens, you can override the lockout by holding the reset button in until the furnace kicks in again.

steps.title: Tighten the screw as soon as the air stops sputtering out and a steady stream of fuel pours out.
steps.content: Tighten the screw as soon as the air stops sputtering out and a steady stream of fuel pours out. Be careful not to tighten it too much. Replacing a stripped bleed screw can be a very costly project.

steps.title: Let the furnace continue to run.
steps.content: Let the furnace continue to run. It should run normally without problems now. If it doesn’t restart the next time, check the line for air again by repeating the bleed process. You may not have gotten all the air out the first time, or you may have a debris blockage in your fuel line.
